channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-13307] Making methods under ScannerV2#next inlineable, faster
item.description:
See parent issue for patch and evidence.

I was looking at graphs of our scan and found that methods were 'too big' to be inlined (looking at jvm compilation and inlining output flags – see parent for list). Changing method size helped some. Let me commit the resultant patch.
item.summary: Making methods under ScannerV2#next inlineable, faster

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Minor patch that just breaks up methods under ScannerV2#next to make them smaller and inlinable. Carried over from the parent issue. Has +1 up in parent.

Cool! Haven't thought in this direction at all.

It's a bit weird though to change code just to make inlining better. Can we increase -XX:MaxInlineSize instead? Apparently it default to 35 bytes (yes bytes). Maybe we can set it to 100 (or another good value that inlines the methods we want).

I'm gonna try that now (or tomorrow).

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12706121/13307.txt
against master branch at commit 8dfed5dc88f1c8008345b22e99224cb945fd0941.
ATTACHMENT ID: 12706121

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

-1 tests included. The patch doesn't appear to include any new or modified tests.
Please justify why no new tests are needed for this patch.
Also please list what manual steps were performed to verify this patch.

+1 hadoop versions. The patch compiles with all supported hadoop versions (2.4.1 2.5.2 2.6.0)

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

+1 javadoc. The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

+1 checkstyle. The applied patch does not increase the total number of checkstyle errors

+1 findbugs. The patch does not introduce any new Findbugs (version 2.0.3) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 lineLengths. The patch does not introduce lines longer than 100

+1 site. The mvn site goal succeeds with this patch.

+1 core tests. The patch passed unit tests in .

Test results: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/13349//testReport/
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/13349//artifact/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-annotations.html

Checkstyle Errors: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/13349//artifact/patchprocess/checkstyle-aggregate.html

Console output: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/13349//console

This message is automatically generated.
Tried with 512 bytes instead of 35, but did not see any end-to-end improvement. Lemme try your patch.

I tried 512 too and started to get ' total inlining greater than DesiredMethodLimit'. It does not run faster. Attached flame graph for my run has same profile as default for MaxInlineSize (same percentage CPU for _next). Would be interested to see if you see any benefit in your rig w/ patch attached here.
Will do it this evening when I have access to a computer.

Ran my rig: 100m rows, 1col, FAST_DIFF encoded, all in block cache, everything filtered at the server.
I did not see a measurable end-to-end improvement.

Might be my JDK (OpenJDK7 build 24.75-b04, mixed mode)

Lemme try some more stuff w/o FAST_DIFF and more columns.

Same rig. This time 4m rows, 5 cols each, no encoding, all in block cache, everything filtered at the server.

Also no measurable end-to-end improvement. Is it possible that the time that was spent in this method is not spent somewhere else? (I got that a lot when I tried to improve memory barriers)

larsh Yeah, will be interested to know if you see a difference. There are some pretty critical methods that could be broken up if there is speed to be had here. Below is partial list:


 @ 249   org.apache.hadoop.hbase.regionserver.ScanQueryMatcher::match (823 bytes)   hot method too big

                                    @ 29   org.apache.hadoop.hbase.regionserver.HRegion$RegionScannerImpl::nextInternal (611 bytes)   hot method too big

                       !              @ 20   org.apache.hadoop.hbase.regionserver.StoreScanner::next (774 bytes)   hot method too big

               !              @ 20   org.apache.hadoop.hbase.regionserver.StoreScanner::next (774 bytes)   hot method too big



               !                              @ 52   org.apache.hadoop.hbase.io.hfile.HFileReaderV3$ScannerV3::blockSeek (734 bytes)   hot method too big

I doubled the MaxInlineSize making it 72 instead of default 34. This seemed to do about same as default but better than the 512. It made my flame graph have a different shape though (the HBB._get is showing again which is odd since it is inlined... previous it seemed to indicate that the hosted method was not inlined... need to dig more).

Also tried with various MaxInlineSize's, nothing translated to a real-life gain.
What JDK are you using? Is your setup the same (i.e. everything in block cache and filtered in the server)?
Oh, and I tests 0.98 w/ and w/o the patch.

Sorry larsh, my comment above went in after yours.

I have filterAll enabled in my PE test so results are not returned – is that what you mean by all filtered at the server (Returning results is a bottle neck to be looked at – 5/16ths of CPUs used – but I got distracted when 14/16ths of CPUs were used when I did not return results to the client but throughput only went up 1/3rd).

Tell me about your test rig again. How many clients? How much of machine you using? Can I try your rig over here?

build 1.7.0_67-b01

Is it possible that the time that was spent in this method is not spent somewhere else? (I got that a lot when I tried to improve memory barriers)

The attached flame graphs show different character as I mess with method sizes and then the tangible throughput diff.

If you see no benefit, I can drop this avenue of investigation. The difference is plain in my little test but if only on my rig it probably not 'real'. As said in parent issue, looking for bigger wins than this
stack For you the whole data is in L1 cache (or L2 cache)?

stack Was just using one client to keep one core 100% busy. Lemme try to keep all cores busy tomorrow. Do you see real end-to-end time improvements?
Maybe the difference is my KV sizes. I use columns of just a few bytes (stores a long), not 1000 bytes as PE does.

BTW, larsh doesn't go to me (smile)

@anoop No seeks. No L2. All in block cache or os cache.

Lars Hofhansl

Do you see real end-to-end time improvements?

Hard to tell. My graphs on mean and median are a little erratic from this time. They show the two runs about the same with the more throughput run maybe higher latency but too erratic to be trusted. Could do longer runs to see if they stabilize better.

Anoop Sam John
Atleast the graphs attached in the parent JIRA were all from LRU Block cache.
Trying branch-1 first. If passes, will make a master branch patch.

This message is automatically generated.

Here are graphs of before and after patch applied to branch-1. ~20% more throughput, less CPU, but more GC.

Here is my scan command (we are NOT returning results):

./hbase/bin/hbase --config ~/conf_hbase org.apache.hadoop.hbase.PerformanceEvaluation --filterAll --rows=100000 --nomapred scanRange1000 10 &> /tmp/scan/$$.1.log &

Here is how I ran it on 5 different servers:

for i in c2020 c2022 c2023 c2024 c2025; do ssh $i " bash ./bin/scans.sh" ; done

Here is the data I am scanning...:

./hbase/bin/hbase --config ~/conf_hbase org.apache.hadoop.hbase.PerformanceEvaluation --valueSize=1024 --valueZipf=true --nomapred=true --rows=10000000 sequentialWrite 10 &> /tmp/scan/$$.1.log &

100M zipfian-sized cells between 0 and 1024 bytes.

Can I get a review? Thanks.

Here is commit comment:


This is for branch-1. Will do a master patch if this passes.



Make methods smaller so inlineable and compilable; saw complaint when -XX:+PrintInlining -XX:+PrintCompilation enabled.

Maintain position in bytebuffer rather than ask BB to do it for us; this made BB#get go away as hotspot in flamegraphs.

Use unsafe to parse shorts rather than have BB do it; faster in micro-benchmarks.

Here is https://reviews.apache.org/r/33226/
Review? Patch is small. Thanks.
Added a Q in RB. Looks great Stack. +1
Thanks for the +1s over in RB Anoop and Ram. I answered the question. I think it does not get in the way of commit. Let me add this in.. before Nick branches.
Committed to branch-1. Here is patch for master branch. Trying hadoopqa.

SUCCESS: Integrated in HBase-TRUNK #6385 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-TRUNK/6385/)
HBASE-13307 Making methods under ScannerV2#next inlineable, faster (stack: rev 92af695ea123c8433dd5970af065e38694c21243)

  • hbase-server/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/regionserver/RSRpcServices.java
  • hbase-common/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/util/Bytes.java
  • hbase-server/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/regionserver/HStore.java
  • hbase-server/src/test/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/regionserver/TestTags.java
  • hbase-server/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/regionserver/HRegion.java
  • hbase-server/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/hbase/io/hfile/HFileReaderImpl.java
Closing issues released in 1.1.0.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Made methods smaller under Scanner#next so inlinable and compilable (was getting 'too big to compile' from hotspot). Use of unsafe to parse shorts rather than use BB#getShort... faster, etc.
